aiDetector.title: AI detector for professional¬†content
aiDetector.description: Ensure every report, proposal or message keeps the quality, originality and transparency you expect, with a clear evaluation of possible AI use.

placeholder.title: Drag your file or paste content here
placeholder.subtitle: We accept .txt, .docx and plain text. Colors will appear by sentence.
placeholder.textareaPlaceholder: Paste your essay or article here...

sampleTexts.iaEssay: This essay was generated with an AI model and uses filler phrases to build a narrative that sounds convincing but slightly repetitive. It leans on the same arguments, recycles connectors like "on the other hand" and avoids concrete details, resulting in a pleasant yet predictable structure. Use it to see how the detector behaves with clearly synthetic text and to view the sentence-level highlights.
sampleTexts.humanArticle:
As Apple and Google transform their voice assistants into chatbots, OpenAI is transforming its chatbot into a voice assistant.
On Monday, the San Francisco artificial intelligence start-up unveiled a new version of its ChatGPT chatbot that can receive and respond to voice commands, images and videos.
‚ÄúWe are looking at the future of the interaction between ourselves and machines,‚Äù said Mira Murati, the company‚Äôs chief technology officer.
sampleTexts.mixedEmail: AI content detection systems are crucial tools for online platforms and businesses to utilize as they allow for the automated identification and screening of harmful, illegal, sensitive or copyrighted material at large scales, helping to remove such content from circulation faster and prevent its spread. Specifically, AI detectors can help find child abuse images, terrorist propaganda, spam, private personal details, misinformation, graphic violence, harassment and illegally posted copyrighted content. This enforcement of community guidelines and legal standards through AI screening upholds safety, privacy, integrity and authenticity online while also respecting intellectual property - ultimately benefiting both users and organizations.

evaluation.aiExplanation: Style is highly repetitive and similar to typical AI-generated text.
evaluation.mixedExplanation: Signals are mixed. Manual review recommended to confirm authorship.
evaluation.humanExplanation: Structure and variation look closer to human-written content.

howItWorks.title: How our AI detector works
howItWorks.subtitle: You only need three steps to get a clear, professional report on possible AI use in your text.

items.title: Add your content
items.description: Copy and paste the text you want to analyze, or type it directly.

items.title: Choose the language
items.description: Optimized for Spanish and English today; more languages coming soon.

items.title: Check the length
items.description: We recommend at least 30‚Äì50 words; free plan: 1,500 characters per analysis.

items.title: Click ‚ÄúDetect now‚Äù
items.description: Start the analysis and get an overall probability.

items.title: See a clear percentage
items.description: We show how likely the whole text was written by AI.

items.title: Review the highlights
items.description: We mark sentences that may be AI-generated so you can inspect them.

items.title: Focus on highlighted parts
items.description: Start with the sentences or paragraphs that were flagged.

items.title: Adjust where needed
items.description: Improve clarity, coherence, and a human tone wherever necessary.

items.title: Re-check if you want
items.description: Run detection again to validate changes; history keeps 90 days.

faqs.title: Frequently asked questions
faqs.subtitle: Clear answers about how we detect AI

item-1.question: What is this AI detector and what can it analyze?
item-1.answer: We estimate the probability that a text was written with models like ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude, DeepSeek or Kimi. It works for research papers, blog posts, professional reports, long emails‚Äîany professional writing.

item-2.question: How does the detector work in broad strokes?
item-2.answer: We analyze structure, rhythm, repetition and word choice, comparing against human and AI examples. We output a global probability and highlight sections worth reviewing; we assess style, not isolated words.

item-3.question: How accurate is it? Can it be wrong?
item-3.answer: It is probabilistic, not an absolute verdict. It is a reliable signal in most cases but false positives/negatives can occur. Use it as one input, not the only decision maker.

item-4.question: How should I read the percentage and highlights?
item-4.answer: The percentage shows how much the overall text resembles AI writing. It does not mean that exact percent of the text is AI. Highlights point to sentences/paragraphs with AI-like style to review more closely.

item-5.question: Minimum length and file formats?
item-5.answer: We recommend at least 30‚Äì50 words. Paste text or upload .docx and plain text (.txt). Very short fragments yield less reliable results in any detector.

item-6.question: Which languages are supported right now?
item-6.answer: Optimized for Spanish and English. We will add more languages once we can ensure good quality.

item-7.question: Is there a free plan? What are the limits?
item-7.answer: Yes. You can use it free with limited detections. For more volume or advanced features, subscription plans lift the limits.

item-8.question: What happens to my texts? Do you store or train on them?
item-8.answer: We do not permanently store your texts or use them to train models. We only process them to generate the report and do not share them with other tools.

item-9.question: Does it work with mixed or paraphrased texts?
item-9.answer: Yes. It can analyze mixes of human and AI sections or paraphrased drafts. The result reflects the overall style‚Äîthe more you edit and personalize, the further it gets from AI patterns.

item-10.question: What if my text is original but flagged as AI?
item-10.answer: Remember it is an estimate. Keep drafts, notes, and edit history as evidence. Use the report as a signal to discuss with teachers/clients/reviewers, not as a substitute for human review.
